item.title: Ticket #7147 (Problems with 700+ categories) updated
item.dc:creator: bi0xid
item.description:
It seems the problem is in class Walker_Category.

When using it in wp_list_categories, it gets the database rows one by one. It's more than 2000 queries in my system!

I must use another way to categorize information instead of categories. Any ideas?

item.title: Ticket #6813 (Press This bookmarklet - quick posting from around the web) updated
item.dc:creator: noel
item.description:
Owner changed

Updates are now going in this ticket.

The latest patch fixes problems with paragraphs being transmitted through instead of just line breaks.

I've also attached the loading-publish.gif.

There is still a problem displaying apostrophes despite coming through clean. (?)

Example. Select "it's" in a webpage, click Press This, you'll now get "it\'s". Publish that post and you'll then get "it's" as you should. Anyone? Bueller?

Looking for the problem.

item.title: Ticket #7145 (Link 'Web Address' field strips pipes) created
item.dc:creator: Jairus
item.description:
When creating a new (or editing an existing) link, all pipes will be stripped from the Web Address field (but not Name or Description).

Thus, it's impossible to use Links to link to any sites which use pipes in their URL structure, such as:

​http://www.hallmark.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/category3|10001|10051|181568|147551;-102001;181568|ecards|Just%20Because

item.title: Ticket #7118 (New media uploader uploads files to the wp-admin directory.) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Somehow, their ABSPATH variable is not getting included in the path returned by wp_upload_dir.

See this forum thread for details: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/182297

item.title: Ticket #6723 (get_page_uri returns invalid URLs for multibyte page slug) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
The urldecode calls were introduced long ago in [1841] (1.3-alpha-4) when for some reason page names were double encoded.

The patch is attached.

item.title: Ticket #6510 ([2.5] wp_list_pages "exclude" arg no longer works as advertised) updated
item.dc:creator: jamescollins
item.description:
Replying to hailin:

This issue is caused by a statement ($rhierarchical? = 0) in post-template.php.

I believe Ryan put there because he wanted to improve the performance of page listing.

post-template.php

Query pages. $rhierarchical? = 0; <== caused the issue !! $pages = get_pages($r);

I can confirm that commenting out this line fixes the problem. This change was made in ticket #5458 (revision [6399]).

item.description: Changed assumed server data return per comment #26 (specifies both unknown and up-to-date)

item.title: Ticket #5117 (WordPress (plugin) updates do not warn about unknown plugins) updated
item.dc:creator: strider72
item.description:
Replying to markjaquith:

Assigning to Matt, as this requires an API change.

I'm assigning this back to Matt, as the ball is back in his court. I've done the PHP end -- we now need a change to the server API.

item.title: Ticket #7144 (Warning message in footer) created
item.dc:creator: johnhennmacc
item.description:
A warning message like the following has appeared in the footer of administration screens in r8092 (I have seen it on several so I assume that the problem is a general one):

Warning: call_user_func_array() [function.call-user-func-array]: First argument is expected to be a valid callback, 'wp_ob_end_flush_all' was given in [path to blog directory]/wp-includes/plugin.php on line 311

item.title: Ticket #7143 (Plugin updater should obey minimum version) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
AFAIK this is taken care of server-side.

If a user is running 2.5, And a plugin requires 2.6, The update notification shouldnt even be sent to the WordPress installation.

Maybe this could be used in conjuction with #5117 to notify that a plugin requires a later version of WordPress?

item.title: Ticket #7143 (Plugin updater should obey minimum version) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
The plugin updater doesn't appear to obey the "minimum version" value for plugins, at least based on the source code.

For example, if a new version of a plugin requires WordPress 2.6, users running the older version of the plugin on WordPress 2.5 shouldn't be nagged to update.
